content:
You don't need thought to figure out your experience of time. Just sit. The answer is everpresent in your experience. Seeking an answer is just more thinking. Don't seek. Just sit. 

In general, where your emotional resistance is, is exactly where you need to focus. What is the discomfort with sitting with your own experience? Your mind is the one generating the discomfort so all you have to do is ask patiently and eventually an answer will manifest. 

There's a question I found meditating on to be helpful since it helps with a shift in focus: What will my next thought be?

seems decent idk his content that well really
in general from what ive gathered, the stuff hes talking about and the stuff jamie is talking about is the same stuff

Suppose we were to accept that it really was you in the past who experienced that event which you now remember. If that was the case that means you existed in the past, and continue to exist into the future. If you examine your experience really closely, is there any direct experience of continuity in time at all? Apart from memory do you have any other indication that time exists?

It may be helpful to ask yourself "What is my experience of time in this present moment?" and see what the mind comes up with. There's a good video but it has a lot of yapping. He asks the question a few times in the middle of the video but for the rest of it he's yapping about galaxies and whatever else. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aCmBpSLdLpA&t=798s

content:
You *finally* get that all thoughts occur in the present or *right now* you can see that all thought occurs in the present? What made you believe that you've experienced a different way of understanding thoughts through time before? Would that not also just be a thought right now? 

Your direct experience of life is the exact same as if you suddenly were placed in a completely functioning body with all its memories. Every moment you are aware you are suddenly placed in a functioning mind and body with absolutely no experience of the past. Your direct experience is instantaneous. 

It could be worth looking at the alien analogy again because it gives a very good intuitive argument for why identifying with the past makes no sense. 

You're most welcome for the help. I'm glad you've found it helpful :)

Suppose you have the thought:
 "if I understand all this thought relationship with time business completely then I will be self-realized." 

In terms of direct experience *right now* being what you actually are, is that true at all? Is there a such thing as becoming self-realized? What exactly is the thing you have been pursuing through inquiry?

Let's see whether this goes anywhere...

Here is Jamie's alien analogy: "I think a good way to point to our misunderstanding of our relationship with time is to imagine there’s an alien who wants to experience what it’s like to be a human. The alien takes you and plugs some wires into your brain and says, I’m going to take over your consciousness for a second to download your memory. Ok close your eyes, and in 10 seconds I’m going to take over. Ok 3 2 1 I’m opening my eyes as a human for the first time. Huh, weird. feet huh?” and they swap back having downloaded the data and the alien says thanks, I understand you now. You might say “what, that’s it? How can you know what it’s like to be me, I had to go through years of self-improvement to get where I am now. I was bullied in school and had two terrible relationships before figuring out who I am now” “yeah I know it was in your memory” “what no, it took like half my life to go through that” “yeah dude I was literally you I know” “no but you can’t know what it was like you didn’t experience it you just sat there, what does it feel like for someone to break up with you?” “Feels bad man” “what, but it didn’t happen to you” “bro, I was literally you. I knew exactly what you know now. It’s in your memories” “what, but. You didn’t… you weren’t there”."

Does any identification with a memory make sense if the alien could always claim "nonono that was me there, that wasn't actually you?" What would make your argument for really being there stronger than the alien's?

To add on to what Jamie said:
What is currently your self-image isn't actually you. It is knowledge about the world that is completely unrelated to what you really are. In terms of navigating the world, this knowledge in itself is very useful, but believing that this knowledge actually represents something about yourself is not.

Understanding your perception of time (or rather your *lack* of perception of time) is the difference between having an intellectual understanding versus really being able to feel it as your actual present reality. I always recommend meditation inquiring into time because it's what I found most helpful. 

Essentially, you have no experience of the past or future at all, so it makes no sense to identify with the construct of an entity who does have experience of the past or future. 

<#1440440742236393472> has a conversation that goes into depth about the misunderstanding of recognizing yourself in your memories, but it is very long. Could be a useful read though.
